Visit 1: Comparing and Contrasting with the Gospel

ENG 106L Lesson 10 PDF

Discussion

Part 1: Together with your speaking partner, discuss the difference in Alma the Younger before and after the angel visited him. You may discuss the sons of Mosiah as well. Refer to Mosiah 27 and Alma 36 or other chapters or verses that you wish to use to compare. Brainstorm and write down a list of as many things that you can think of that changed in his life. Also, compare the different ways that Alma the Younger felt before the angel and after the angel spoke to him, when he could not move because he "was struck with such great fear and amazement" in Alma 36:12-22. If you think of ways that he is similar, write those down as well.

Part 2: Discuss how the gospel has changed each of you. For example, you may discuss some of the following:

  1. Look at the list that you wrote down about Alma the Younger and/or the sons of Mosiah and compare that list to your life. In what ways is Alma the Younger or are the sons of Mosiah similar to or different from you?
  2. How have certain gospel principles changed you from earlier in your life?
  3. What is something you have learned now or at some point in your life that has helped you? How has that knowledge helped you?

Speaking

Part 1: Choose a topic from the topic list for Week 10 for your speaking partner to compare and contrast. Ask any questions you have related to the topic they described.

Part 2: Your speaking partner will choose a topic from the list for you to compare and contrast. Make sure you provide any background information necessary for them to understand what you are describing and then compare and contrast that item. Answer any questions the speaking partner may have.

Visit 2: Timed Writing Assignment


During this part of the session, you will do a timed writing assignment. You will write at least three paragraphs. It will be related to the content in the unit. Your speaking partner will give you the topic from the topic list. You will plan and write a short essay.

Step 1: Open a new, blank document in Microsoft Word.

Step 2: Plan your writing (2-4 minutes).

Step 3: Write your short essay (10-12 minutes).

Step 4: Edit your writing (2-4 minutes).

Step 5: Save your writing.

Step 6: Copy and paste your writing into the instant message area on Skype. Your Speaking Partner will read it and give you feedback during your tutor session. Think of at least one question you can ask your Speaking Partner about something that will help you improve what you wrote.

Step 7: If you wish, revise your writing. Use the feedback your Speaking Partner discussed with you. Save your writing again.

Step 8: After your session, answer the questions above. Then copy and paste your writing into the box as well. Your instructor will read through it and may also give you some feedback.

Discussion with Speaking Partner: Study Habits

You are now more than half way through the course. Read the test strategies listed below with your speaking partner. Discuss each strategy and how it can help you in taking tests.

  • Read the directions carefully.
  • Know if each question has one or more correct options.
  • Know how much time is allowed.
  • Preview the test.
  • Read through the test quickly and answer the easiest questions first.
  • Read through the test a second time and answer more difficult questions.
  • You may pick up cues for answers from the first reading, or become more comfortable in the testing situation.
  • If time allows, review both questions and answers.
  • It is possible you mis-read questions the first time.

(Visit this website if you wish to learn more about improving your test-taking skills: Study Guides and Strategies)

Reading Out Loud

If there is time, your speaking partner will ask you to read the story "Laie." Practice reading out loud with your partner or until you can read it smoothly.

Laie

Laie has changed since 1865 in the way the community members provide for their families. When Laie was first settled, in 1865, the people survived by fishing. Fishing was a community effort back then, unlike today. Today, people support their families by working at Brigham Young University-Hawaii (BYU-H) and the Polynesian Cultural Center (PCC). Back in the early days, the Laie community members realized that they needed to do more than fish if they wanted their children to improve economically, so they set up the first Hukilau show. This show was a smaller version of the Polynesian Cultural Center. It started out with only two villages represented, Hawaii and Samoa, and expanded to what the Polynesian Cultural Center is today. Tourists would come to this Hukilau show and pay $2.50 to help pull in the fishing nets. Similarly, tourists today come from all over the world to watch the Polynesian Cultural Center show. However, the price is much higher now than when the show first started. Today, Laie families continue to survive by their skill and resourcefulness.
